title.value: Existing Digital Health Technology Index Summary Report for Older Adults Living with Neurocognitive Disorders (Mild and Major) and Their Informal Caregivers: An Environmental Scan
title.justification: The title clearly reflects the focus of the paper on summarizing existing digital health technologies for older adults with neurocognitive disorders and their caregivers.
title.quote: Existing Digital Health Technology Index Summary Report for Older Adults Living with Neurocognitive Disorders (Mild and Major) and Their Informal Caregivers: An Environmental Scan

extractions.description: The paper conducts an environmental scan to evaluate and categorize existing digital health technologies aimed at supporting older adults with mild and major neurocognitive disorders and their informal caregivers. It highlights the availability, purpose, and scientific backing of various digital solutions in Canada and Europe.

type.justification: The paper involves conducting an environmental scan to assess existing digital health solutions, which is a form of empirical research as it deals with systematically gathering and analyzing data.
type.quote: This environmental scan was performed to identify the features of existing digital health solutions relevant to the targeted population.

name.justification: The paper focuses on digital health technologies aimed at improving the well-being of people with neurocognitive disorders, which positions the research primarily in the field of Digital Health.
name.quote: Digital health has added numerous promising solutions to enhance the health and wellness of people with neurocognitive disorders (NCDs) and their informal caregivers.

name.justification: The research targets older adults with neurocognitive disorders, implicating geriatric considerations in its scope.
name.quote: Digital health technology utilization has changed the way older adults live in and out of their homes.

name.justification: The paper specifically addresses technologies for mild and major neurocognitive disorders, such as dementia.
name.quote: The number of people with mild or major neurocognitive disorders (NCDs) will rise to 70 million by 2030 and 139 million by 2050.
